TEXT.TEXTVALUE: Click on any of the given volumes of the nickel solution in a small reagent bottle to start the estimation.
Pour the selected volume of nickel in a 100ml standard flask.
Place a funnel in the mouth of the standard flask.
Place a funnel on the mouth of the standard flask.
Keep a glass rod on the funnel.
Now, pour the entire nickel solution to the standard flask.
Pour some distilled water into the reagent bottle and shake it well.
Pour the solution into the standard flask using a glass rod.
Repeat the same procedure until the entire nickel solution is transferred to the standard flask.
Repeat the same procedure until the entire nickel solution is transferred to the standard flask.
Remove the glass rod and funnel from the standard flask.
Make up the nickel solution to 100ml using water.
Close the standard flask using a stopper.
Shake the flask well.
Take a clean beaker.
Open the stopper of the flask.
Take 20ml of Nickel solution from the flask using a pipette.
Take 20ml of Nickel solution from the flask using a pipette.
Pour the pipetted solution into the beaker.
Pour the pipetted solution into the beaker.
Take 5ml of 1:1 HCl into a measuring jar.
Take 5ml of 1:1 HClinto a measuring jar.
Take 5ml of 1:1 HCl into a measuring jar.
Add it into the beaker containing Nickel solution.
Pour some distilled water into the solution.
Stir the solution using a glass rod.
Heat the solution using heating mantle at 70°C -80°C.
Heat the solution using a heating mantle set at 70°C -80°C.
Take 20 ml of Dimethyl Glyoxime in a measuring jar.
Take 20 ml of Dimethyl Glyoxime in a measuring jar.
Remove the solution from the heating mantle.
Add it to the heated solution.
Take dil.Ammonia solution using a dropper.
Add it into the solution.
Stir it well using glass rod.
Repeat the step, till the solution smells like ammonia.
Repeat the step, till the solution smells like ammonia.
Repeat the step, till the solution smells like ammonia.
A red precipitate is formed in the beaker.
Heat the solution using a water bath for 30 minutes.
Allow it to cool using a cool water tray.
Remove the beaker containing the sintered crucible from the air oven using tongs.
Remove the beaker containing the sintered crucible from the air oven using tongs.
Place the beaker on a tile for some time using tongs (cooling).
Keep the beaker containing sintered crucible in a desiccator for 15 minutes.
Take the sintered crucible from the desiccator using tongs.
Measure the mass of the empty sintered crucible using a weighing balance as shown.
Place the filtration flask into a stand and connect the side tube of the filter flask to the suction pump.
Place the filtration flask into a stand and connect the side tube of the filter flask to the suction pump.
Close the flask using a rubber cork.
Place the sintered crucible on top of it.
Take the beaker containing cooled red precipitate from the tray.
Slowly pour the red solution into the sintered crucible using a glass rod.
Pour some distilled water into the beaker to transfer quantitatively all the precipitate into the sintered crucible.
Pour the solution into the sintered crucible using glass rod.
We can observe that a red precipitate is left in the bottom of the sintered crucible.
Take few drops of [cml]AgNO3[/cml] solution into a test tube.
Remove the sintered crucible from the cork and collect some drops in a test tube as shown.
A white precipitate indicates the presence of chloride in the solution.
Wash the precipitate with distilled water and scrub the beaker well using a policeman to remove the particles adherring to the beaker.
Transfer it into the sintered crucible.
Repeat the test for chlorine. No white ppt is formed. This indicates the absence of chloride ions.
Remove the sintered crucible from the rubber cork using tongs.
Place the beaker containing sintered crucible into an air oven for heating and close the air oven.
Set the oven at 110°C -120°C for 30 minutes.
Open the air oven and take the beaker containing sintered crucible from the air oven using tongs.
Place it on a tile.
Using tongs, place the sintered crucible into the desiccator for 15 minutes for further cooling.
Open the desiccator and take out the beaker containing sintered crucible.
Measure the weight of the sintered crucible containing red precipitate using the weighing balance. Repeat drying and reweigh until a constant weight is obtained.
Equation
